title: CRIAR
summary: CRIAR is a team-based, on-the-spot bridge-building competition at Megalith. Teams design a bridge on paper and then construct a physical model using only provided materials.
details: CRIAR is a team-based bridge-building competition conducted during Megalith. It is an on-the-spot event where the problem statement is given at the venue. Teams of 2 to 5 members participate, and team members cannot be changed after registration. The event has two rounds: a preliminary round where teams prepare a detailed bridge design on paper, and a final round where shortlisted teams construct a bridge model using only the materials provided. External materials or supports are not allowed. Judging is based on load-bearing capacity, structural stability, material optimization, creativity, and aesthetic appeal. Judges’ decisions are final.
rules: Problem statement is given on the spot at the venue.
Teams must have 2 to 5 members and cannot change after registration.
The bridge model must be constructed only with materials provided by the organizers.
No external materials or supports are allowed.
tools_or_materials: Only materials provided by the organizers.
disqualifications: Use of external materials or supports

title: Instridge
summary: Instridge is an on-the-spot arch bridge design and construction competition. Teams design and build an arch bridge using only organizer-provided materials under strict dimensional and safety rules.
details: Instridge is an on-the-spot arch bridge design and construction competition. It is a team event with 2 to 5 members per team, and team composition cannot be changed after registration. Participants design and construct an arch bridge, focusing on efficient load distribution and structural stability. Only materials provided by the organizers may be used, and all specified dimensional and safety rules must be followed. Teams are judged on strength, efficiency, stability, construction time, innovation, teamwork, and aesthetics. Copied designs or unsafe practices lead to penalties or disqualification.
rules: Teams must have 2 to 5 members and cannot change composition after registration.
Only materials provided by the organizers may be used.
All specified dimensional and safety rules must be strictly followed.
tools_or_materials: Only materials provided by the organizers.

title: BEAT-D-EUCLID
summary: BEAT-D-EUCLID is an individual CAD-based competition using AutoCAD. Participants build a 3D model from given orthographic views within a time limit.
details: BEAT-D-EUCLID is an individual, on-the-spot CAD-based competition conducted using AutoCAD. Participants are given top, front, and left-hand side views and must create an accurate 3D model within the given time limit. Participants must bring their own laptops with AutoCAD installed, and no other software or reference drawings are allowed. Judging is based on accuracy, dimensional correctness, command efficiency, visualization skills, and presentation quality. Pre-made models or plagiarism result in disqualification.
rules: The competition is strictly individual.
Participants must use AutoCAD and bring their own laptops with AutoCAD installed.
Only the provided orthographic views may be used; no external reference drawings are allowed.
The model must be completed within the given time limit.
tools_or_materials: Participant’s own laptop with AutoCAD installed.

title: Innovators Conclave
summary: Innovators Conclave is a role-based infrastructure problem-solving event. Teams take on stakeholder roles and present balanced solutions to a given infrastructure challenge.
details: Innovators Conclave is a team-based role-playing infrastructure problem-solving event. Teams consist of 4 to 5 members, with each participant assigned a stakeholder role. The task is to analyze a given infrastructure problem and propose a balanced solution considering technical, economic, environmental, and social factors. Teams present their solution in a 5–7 minute presentation followed by a 3–5 minute Q&A session, with one member delivering the conclusion. Judging is based on collaboration, creativity, originality, feasibility, and representation of stakeholder perspectives. Judges’ decisions are final.
rules: Teams must have 4 to 5 members, each assigned a distinct stakeholder role.
Teams must analyze the given infrastructure problem from multiple perspectives: technical, economic, environmental, and social.
Presentation duration is 5–7 minutes followed by a 3–5 minute Q&A session.
One member should deliver the final conclusion of the presentation.

title: LIFTOVATE
summary: LIFTOVATE is a hydraulic lift engineering challenge for teams. Participants design and demonstrate a hydraulic lifting mechanism without using motors or electrical components.
details: LIFTOVATE is a hydraulic lift engineering challenge conducted as an on-the-spot team event. Teams of 4 to 5 members design and demonstrate a hydraulic lifting mechanism based on fluid mechanics and pressure transmission principles. Motors and electrical components are not allowed, and only approved materials may be used. The event includes a model presentation followed by lifting tasks. Evaluation is based on functionality, smooth operation, stability, precision, time efficiency, innovation, and safety. Rule violations lead to disqualification.
rules: Teams must have 4 to 5 members.
The lifting mechanism must be based on fluid mechanics and pressure transmission principles.
Motors and electrical components are strictly not allowed.
Only materials approved or provided by the organizers may be used.
tools_or_materials: Only organizer-approved materials; no motors or electrical components.
disqualifications: Violation of material restrictions or safety rules

title: The Green Canvas
summary: The Green Canvas is a team-based environmental case study competition focused on sustainable real-world solutions. It includes abstract submission and a final presentation at IIT Kharagpur.
details: The Green Canvas is a team-based environmental case study competition focused on sustainable and real-world solutions. Teams of 2 to 5 members participate in two phases: Phase 1 involves online abstract submission limited to one page, with an additional page allowed for visuals, and Phase 2 consists of a final presentation at IIT Kharagpur. Topics may include renewable energy, pollution control, and urban planning. Judging is based on data usage, analysis, feasibility, innovation, sustainability, and presentation quality. Plagiarism is strictly prohibited.
rules: Teams must have 2 to 5 members.
Phase 1 requires an online abstract submission limited to one page, with an additional page allowed for visuals.
Phase 2 consists of a final presentation at IIT Kharagpur.
Topics should focus on sustainable, real-world environmental or infrastructure solutions.
tools_or_materials: Digital tools for abstract preparation and presentation materials.

title: Model Exhibition
summary: Model Exhibition is a civil engineering model design competition for teams. Participants design and present models based on civil engineering themes using approved materials.
details: Model Exhibition is a civil engineering model design competition conducted as a team event with 2 to 5 members per team. Participants design and present models based on civil engineering-related themes. Pre-made models are not allowed, and only approved materials such as wood and cardboard may be used. Teams must explain the concept, technical feasibility, real-world application, and sustainability of their model. Judging is based on innovation, feasibility, detailing, aesthetics, and practicality. Judges’ decisions are final.
rules: Teams must have 2 to 5 members.
Models must be based on civil engineering-related themes.
Pre-made models are not allowed.
Only approved materials such as wood and cardboard may be used.
tools_or_materials: Approved materials such as wood and cardboard; basic model-making tools.

title: Darkode
summary: Darkode is a competitive coding contest at Megalith. Participants solve algorithmic and data structure problems individually or in small teams within a strict time limit.
details: Darkode is a competitive coding contest conducted during Megalith. Participants can compete individually or in teams of up to three members. Problems are based on algorithms and data structures, and languages such as C, C++, Python, and Java are allowed. The event has a strict time limit, and scoring is based on accuracy, efficiency, and optimized solutions. Plagiarism, AI-generated code, or external help is strictly prohibited and leads to disqualification.
rules: Participants may compete individually or in teams of up to three members.
Problems are based on algorithms and data structures.
Allowed languages typically include C, C++, Python, and Java.
Solutions must be submitted within the specified time limit.
Use of AI-generated code or external help is strictly prohibited.
tools_or_materials: Laptop with coding environment and internet/platform access as specified by organizers.
disqualifications: External help or collusion beyond the registered team

title: Survey Hunt
summary: Survey Hunt is an on-the-spot treasure hunt based on surveying and navigation skills. Teams use surveying instruments to navigate checkpoints within a time limit.
details: Survey Hunt is an on-the-spot team-based treasure hunt event that applies surveying and navigation skills. Teams of 2 to 5 members navigate through multiple checkpoints using only the surveying instruments provided by the organizers. The event has a time limit, and scoring is based on accuracy, time efficiency, strategy, and teamwork. Penalties are imposed for wrong answers, and external help or interference is not allowed. Judges’ decisions are final.
rules: Teams must have 2 to 5 members.
Teams must use only the surveying instruments provided by the organizers.
Teams must navigate through multiple checkpoints within the specified time limit.
External help or interference is not allowed.
Penalties are imposed for wrong answers.
tools_or_materials: Surveying instruments provided by the organizers.
disqualifications: Use of external help or interference

title: Megalith Overview
summary: Megalith is the annual civil engineering fest of IIT Kharagpur featuring technical, analytical, and creative events. It provides a platform for students to apply classroom knowledge to real-world problems.
details: Megalith is the annual civil engineering fest that hosts a wide range of technical, analytical, and creative events for students. It provides a platform to apply classroom knowledge to real-world engineering problems through competitions, case studies, model building, coding, and quizzes. The theme of Megalith 2024 was 'STHYATITVA – Transforming into a Sustainable World', emphasizing sustainability, innovation, and responsible engineering.

title: Megalith and Organizing Institute
summary: Megalith is India’s largest civil engineering technical fest organized by the Department of Civil Engineering under the Civil Engineering Society at IIT Kharagpur. It offers competitions, problem-solving events, and learning opportunities.
details: Megalith is India’s largest civil engineering technical fest, organized by the Department of Civil Engineering under the aegis of the Civil Engineering Society, IIT Kharagpur. It is hosted at the Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur, the first IIT of the nation, established in 1951. The fest provides a platform for engineering students to test their skills through exciting competitions, real-world problem-solving events, prizes, and learning opportunities in a highly competitive environment.

title: Megalith Internship Program
summary: The Megalith Internship Program allows students to work closely with the fest’s organizing team. Interns promote Megalith in their colleges and build networks and leadership skills.
details: The Megalith Internship Program offers students an opportunity to work closely with the organizing team of Megalith, the civil engineering fest of IIT Kharagpur. Interns act as a vital link between Megalith and students across various colleges by leveraging their networks, promoting the fest, and fostering collaboration. The program helps interns connect with the IIT Kharagpur community while gaining exposure to event management, communication, and leadership within the civil engineering ecosystem.

title: Megalith Internship Program Incentives
summary: The Megalith Internship Program offers certificates, leadership opportunities, potential free accommodation, networking, LinkedIn endorsements, and official merchandise as incentives.
details: The Megalith Internship Program offers multiple incentives including an official certificate of internship from the Head of the Department, opportunities to develop leadership skills, free accommodation based on performance and registration in Megalith, professional networking across colleges, LinkedIn endorsements for skills, and official Megalith merchandise. These incentives aim to reward performance while enhancing professional growth and visibility.

title: Responsibilities of a Megalith Intern
summary: Megalith Interns act as points of contact between Megalith and their colleges. They promote the fest, drive participation, and coordinate related activities.
details: A Megalith Intern is responsible for creating awareness about Megalith and IIT Kharagpur by acting as the point of contact between the fest and their college. Interns are expected to leverage their social media networks for fest promotion, work with the Megalith team to ensure quality participation in events, and coordinate with the organizing team to help organize Megalith-related activities within their college.
rules: Act as the primary point of contact between Megalith and the home college.
Promote Megalith through social media and college networks.
Encourage and coordinate student participation in Megalith events.
Help organize Megalith-related activities or sessions within the college.
